thread.title: UPDATE 1-Indonesia's Bank Mandiri profit jumps 49 pct as bad loan provisions drop

author: Reuters Editorial
title: UPDATE 1-Indonesia's Bank Mandiri profit jumps 49 pct as bad loan provisions drop
text:
(Adds details of results, outlook)
JAKARTA, Feb 6 (Reuters) - PT Bank Mandiri, Indonesia’s largest bank by assets, posted a 49 percent jump in net profit last year, helped by a fall in provisions for soured loans as well as a rapid growth in fee-based income.
For 2018, Mandiri expects a loan growth of around 11-12 percent. That is in line with the financial services regulator’s estimate of 10-12 percent growth for the sector as growth picks up from sluggish levels that followed a sharp downturn in commodities.
The state-controlled bank said net income came in at 20.6 trillion rupiah ($1.52 billion) in 2017, rebounding strongly after booking its worst profit in five years in 2016.
That was slightly above the average estimate of 20.3 trillion rupiah drawn from 17 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
“A significant decline in provisioning cost had resulted in a significant profit growth,” CEO Kartika Wirjoatmodjo told reporters on Tuesday.
He said the bank had managed to cut its provisions for bad loans by 35 percent to around 15.95 trillion rupiah, in line with its goal of 16 trillion-18 trillion rupiah.
The bank lowered its gross non-performing loan ratio to 3.46 percent, from 4 percent a year earlier.
Mandiri has been under pressure to tackle bad debt after provisions doubled to 24.6 trillion rupiah in 2016 as non-performing loans spread beyond the commodities sector to consumer-related businesses.
Fee-based income grew by 16.4 percent in 2017, more than double its growth rate in the previous year, it said.
The bank also said it extended 729.5 trillion rupiah in loans as of the end of 2017, an annual increase of 10.2 percent, helped by robust demand from the corporate and consumer segments.
Mandiri’s net interest income rose 1 percent while its net interest margin stood at 5.87 percent vs 6.44 percent in 2016. ($1 = 13,550 rupiah) (Reporting by Cindy Silviana; Writing by Fransiska Nangoy; Editing by Edwina Gibbs and Gopakumar Warrier)
